2. A 5-year-old girl is referred to the hematology clinic due to recurrent infections and poor weight gain despite adequate nutrition. Her parents note that she frequently develops painful mouth ulcers and has episodes of diarrhea. On examination, she has a distended abdomen with palpable hepatomegaly and mild splenomegaly. Laboratory workup shows persistent neutropenia and episodes of hypoglycemia after short fasting periods. A history of delayed growth and episodes of lethargy during illness is reported. Liver enzyme analysis reveals glycogen accumulation, and genetic testing identifies mutations in the SLC37A4 gene. Bone marrow evaluation is notable for myeloid hypoplasia, explaining her recurrent infections. These clinical and laboratory findings are consistent with Glycogen Storage Disease Type Ib.

output:
